Summary

This section is designed to give a comprehensive summary of all the ways something can go wrong on a Faraday. Failure Modes have been broken in the four categories: Mechanical, electrical, firmware and intervention complications. The the first three are self-explanatory. The fourth section tries to summarise things that can go wrong when customer or mechanics attempt to repair the Faraday.

Mechanical

WHEEL INSTALLATION

Overview
Every Faraday bicycle requires the front wheel to be installed during assembly. Improperly installing the front wheel can lead to fork damage, motor core damage and potentially harm the rider.

Symptoms

  • Wheel spins in the dropout
  • The motor cables wraps around the motor core

Repair
The steel dropout can often be straightened. A motor core with damage to the wire harness needs to be replaced immediately.

Prevention
Follow correct wheel installation procedures, using all the included hardware and tightening the nuts to 30Nm. Proper installation procedure should also be communicated to the customer in the case that they remove the wheel to replace a flat. You can also find a video guide here. The "no-turn" washer tends to cause the most trouble. With the wheel oriented so that the motor cable is facing down, the no-turn washer should be installed against the hub with the tab facing down and out.

Pictures

The dropout may be spread if the wheel spins in place. You may be able to hammer it back to 10mm diameter


A motor core with damage to the wire harness needs to be replaced immediately

MOTOR EXTENSION CABLE CONNECTION

Overview
The Porteur and Cortland both are susceptible to the motor cable coming loose. This can cause abrupt loss of power to the motor or even make the motor core spin backwards

Symptom

  • The bike randomly stops assisting while riding
  • The assist never worked on a new bike
  • The motor cable slides 2+ inches out of the frame when pulled on
  • The motor starts to spin backward

Repair
Cortland:

  1. Open the seat tube access panel
  2. Fish out the motor cables and reconnect them
  3. Add extra zip ties around the bullet connectors before reinstalling

Porteur:

  1. Pull the controller and reconnect the barrel connect
  2. Make sure all three crimps are level by pressing them foward with a needle nose plier (see picture).
  3. Follow the controller installation guide

Prevention

  • Porteur - Make sure the barrel connection is snapped into place during a controller replacement
  • Cortland - Add 2+ zip ties to bullet connectors making sure to tie them around all three cables at once.

Pictures


It's important to place a zip tie on both the first and last bullet connector, securing it against the other wires


Twist the barrel connect ring until there is a distinct sensation of it locking into place


The pins need to be level to make good contact. If one is loose, the motor may stutter or even sping backward

SEATPOST WELD

Overview
The weld on certain Porteur seat posts has snapped. This is a very serious issue that has led to both damaged bikes and injuries. As of Q4 2018, there have been five incidents.

Symptom

  • Seatpost snaps at the seam between the post and top mount

Repair

  1. Replace the seat post immediately
  2. Report issue to Pon lawyer

Prevention

  • Replace 2014 seat posts proactively - usually Porteur bikes with mechanical brakes
  • Make sure the saddle is not past the maximum position on the seat post.

Pictures


The seat post always fails around the weld


The year of manufacture can be found just underneath the 25.4 diameter


One should avoid moving the saddle beyond the maximum rail position

TOPTUBE PIN ALIGNMENT

Overview
The M5 connector is found on the toptube, selector, headlight and programming cable. The four pin connector is indexed but can be overridden when screwed together. This can either force the pins into the wrong socket or bend them.

Symptom

  • Bike defaults to regular assist irrespective to the mode selected
  • Bike fails to communicate to the computer
  • Controller fails to load past bootloader (red LEDs do not illuminate)

Repair
The pins can often be straightened if carefully moved back into place with a razor blade or tweezers. Repeated bending will fatigue the metal and snap the pins off. At that point, the only option is replacing the top tube cable.

Prevention
The arrows show the proper alignment of the connector. Double check the arrows before proceeding. Press the connection together as far as it will go before proceeding to screw completely. You should feel very little resistance.

Pictures


The pins tend to twist in the same direction


Repeated bending of the bins can fatigue the metal to the point a pin breaks off

TDCM BB PLAY

Overview
The tolerances on a particular batch of TDCM bottom brackets, can have substantial amounts of play in the normal direction from the spindle. Excessive tightening of the cup does not always remove the play ( 2+mm). For more details checking out this article.

Symptom

  • Clicking sounds on each pedal stroke
  • The pedals feel crooked or uneven

Repair
Replace bottom bracket with NCTE and updating the motor paramaters.

Prevention
N/A

Pictures


If there is still play after tightening the cup to 30Nm, the bottom bracket will need to be replaced

PLANETARY GEAR PREMATURE DEGRADATION

Overview
On the first American built Porteurs, the teeth were cut too sharp in the planetary gears. This lead to premature depletion of the nylon gears and contamination that would lead to further degradation. The motors will begin to make noise and ultimately lose power. This older motor design is not compatible with new motors so a new hub will need to be sent out and the wheel re-laced.

Symptom

  • Grinding noise coming from the motor
  • Reduced power

Repair
We no longer stock 8fun motor cores so a new hub will need to laced into the rim. The motor parameters should also be updated after this procedure from 36V to 43V.

Prevention
N/A

Pictures


The beveled teeth found in the 43V motors extend the longevity.

SELECTOR CLAMP OVERSTRESS

Overview
The selector clamp is plastic and not designed to be tightened beyond 0.5Nm. Tightening the bolt beyond this point will fatigue the plastic. Micro fissures will appear and ultimately lead to total failure.

Symptom

  • Thin cracks may appear in the plastic clamp
  • The internal nut may pull out of the plastic shell entirely

Repair
A replacement plastic clamp may be sent out. The hardware will need to be removed from the old clamp and installed in the new clamp. When replacing the clamp it's wise to place a piece of tape on the first two sections so they do not separate and release the bearings.

Prevention
Do not tighten the clamp over 0.5 Nm or roughly half a turn beyond when the selector no longer spins freely on the handlebars.

Pictures


Microcracks indicate the clamp has been overtightened


At this point the clamp is no longer functional

CONTROLLER CHARGING PORT SHORT

Overview
Due to poor tolerances and solder joints, some controllers can spontaneously short on the 51V input. The charger will arc between the shell of the plug and the controller shell.

Symptom

  • A loud electrical popping sound when a charger is plugged in
  • Charing to either the charger connector or port

Repair
Replace both the controller and charger immediately.

Prevention
The issue can manifest itself at any point without external cause.

Pictures


Soot or melted metal requires an immediate controller replacement

RUSTED DOWN TUBE

Overview
Removing the battery can become difficult if too much rust accumulates in the downtube. Mostly first-gen bike were susceptible. In the worse case scenario the frame would need to be replaced.

Symptom

  • Unable to remove the battery from the bike
  • Noticeable rust around the eccentric shell

Repair
Feel free to pull aggressively on the main power cable coming from the battery. For additional leverage, a long 3mm bolt can be threaded into the face of the battery and then grabbed with a pair of vice grips. In extreme cases, the frame will need to be replaced.

Prevention
Putting a little grease on the new battery lowers the chance of the issue happening.

Pictures


Threading a screw into this port can provide extra leverage while removing a battery

STURMEY ARCHER HUB FAILURE

Overview
Sturmey Archer Hubs have a limited working life. In as little as a thousand miles they can show signs of wear.

Symptom

  • Grinding noise during regular use
  • Gears skipping or slipping even after cable tensions is set correctly

Repair
Replace the hub or recommend the customer upgrade their bike to a Shimano Nexus.

Prevention
Keep the cable tension correctly tensioned.

Pictures


If the gears are slipping make sure the cable tension is correct by lining up the yellow and red lines when the twist shifter is in position 2

Electrical

BATTERY DEEP DISCHARGE

Overview
The greater majority of Faraday batteries were shipped with a design flaw that caused a high quiescent current and self-discharge to critically low voltages. The battery, even when disconnected from a load, was capable of discharging at around the rate of 1mAh. This allows the pack to fully discharge from a full charge to critically low within one year.

Symptom

  • Bike fails to turn on
  • LED on charger remains green when plugged in
  • Customer leaves bike overnight to charge with no result
  • Headlight stays on when charger is plugged in

Repair
A sleeping battery can sometimes be recovered if the pack voltage is above 12V. At this voltage, the BMS SOC will momentarily turn on allowing some current to flow in the cells.

  1. To best revive a battery connect it to a power supply set to 33V and 200mA.
  2. Toggle a power switch repeatedly until current starts to flow steadily.
  3. Once charged to 33V switch over to a standard charger
  4. Check cell balance after the battery is fully charged
    For more details check out this article: Battery Recovery(TODO)

Prevention
It is essential to communicate proper charging procedures to both dealers and customers. For more details check out this article. Bikes in storage need to be fully charged every 12 months.

Pictures


A sleeping battery will be unable to provide power to the controller


The green LED shows no charge is flowing in the battery.

BATTERY CELL IMBALANCE

Overview
Cell defects or poor assembly can cause issues with balancing the pack. If a cell deviates more than 50mV from the pack mean, it is likely to continue to get worse. This can interfere with charging and reduce the packs capacity. The check for cell balance refer to the Cell Balance Guide.

Symptom

  • The bike is unable to charge to 100 percent
  • Bike is showing substantially reduced range
  • The battery level on a working mode selector shows mostly full but the bike still turns itself off soon after being turned on.

Repair
Discharging the battery and then charging it with a power supply at 500mA can sometimes restore cell balance.

Prevention
The issue stems from a manufacturing defect. However one should avoid charging a battery at more the 2000mA.

Pictures


If the cells become this unbalanced, you will need to discard the battery


Good cell balance will be within 50mV of the pack average

SELECTOR TRANSIENT VOLTAGE SUSCEPTIBILITY

Overview
An undersized capacitor in the selector power input circuit is susceptible to transient voltage. Random noise in the 12V input exacerbates the issue and can cause the capacitor to fail. When this happens the selector's chipset will often be destroyed.

Symptom

  • Bike remains in regular assist irrespective of the mode selected
  • The battery gauge no longer refreshes
  • The selector does not report firmware version or except firmware updates from the Faraday Utility

Repair
The selector is beyond repair and must be replaced.

Prevention
This is a design defect.

Pictures


When the capacitor fails, the board can show noticeable heat damage around the power input.

WATER INGRESS

Overview
The controller is not as water resistant as hoped. Water can enter through the controller's charging port. On the Cortland, the water then runs down the RCB causing electrical damage. This can manifest itself as a “ghost power symptom” where the bike turns itself on. Within 48 hours this symptom can discharge the battery completely. It can also cause a range of other strange behaviors.

Symptom

  • Bike starts turning itself on
  • Bike no longer powers on at all after a rainstorm
  • Water pours out of the bottom bracket after the battery access cap is removed

Repair
Some controllers will dry out over time. Otherwise the controller must be replaced. If the battery is not disconnected in time it will need to be woken up or replaced.

Prevention
Cortlands should not be ridden in the rain or stored outside. If the controller starts to display the ghost power symptom, it is important to immediately disconnect it from the battery to stop discharging. Opening the battery access cap on the bottom bracket can also help with drainage.

Pictures


Rust around the controller shell is indicative that the bike was exposed to standing water


Disconnect the battery immediately after the symptom manifests to save it from dying

CHARGE DETECT PIN

Overview
On occasion, the charge detection pin inside the controller will fail. When this happens the bike not longer recognises when the charger has been plugged in and will no longer initiate charging.

Symptom

  • Hooking up a charger does not start charging the bike

Repair
Replace the controller.

Prevention
This is a quite rare manufacturing defect.

Pictures


If no current is flowing the LED will be green on the charger

BURNT OUT LED DRIVER

Overview
The LED driver on the RCB can fail. At this point, it will no longer be able to power the headlight.

Symptom

  • The headlight stops working

Repair
Replace the controller.

Prevention
N/A

Pictures


The the LED is still dead after the connections have been checked it's likely the driver has burnt out

FAILED RS45 TRANSCEIVER

Overview
On occasion, the RCB transceiver will fail. When this happens the bike will turn on but will not assist

Symptom

  • The bike no longer provides assistance or updates the selector battery gauge
  • Only the battery firmware version is returned in when system info is run from the Faraday Utility.

Repair
The controller needs to be replaced.

Prevention
This is a rare hardware defect.

Pictures


If the controller transceiver is bad, the utility will only be able to talk to the battery

FAILED PROGRAMMING CABLE

Overview
The Faraday programming cables have a high failure rate. They can randomly stop working. In addition the plastic housing can physically break off.

Symptom

  • The programming cable no longer communicates with the selector, controller or battery.
  • The USB plug is moving around in the plastic shell

Repair
Replace the programming cable.

Prevention
N/A

Pictures


The shells can also break off the programming cables

CHARGER FAILURE

Overview
Chargers can fail. This usually takes the form failed output under load. Check pin three for 50.4V. The LED should turn red if the >200mA is flowing from the charger. If the charger never turns green when connected to a working bike, it is likely damaged.
Symptom

  • Charger LED never illuminates at all
  • Bike does not enter charge mode

Repair
Replace the charger

Prevention
Stop the charger from overheating by placing it somewhere with plenty of airflow.

Pictures


The red LED indicates that charge is flowing into the battery. It is the best indicator that the bike is actually charging

BB SENSOR FAILURE

Overview
The bottom bracket sensors can fail in a variety of ways. This includes salt, water ingress, crushed sensors or strained connectors.

Symptom

  • Assist only kicks in on half of a pedal stroke
  • Assist kicks in momentarily and then cuts out
  • Assist is on but underpowered

Repair

  1. Double check the TDCM BB was installed correctly TDCM Installation Guide.
  2. Check the sensor to make sure it was not crushed during installation.
  3. For NCTE BB, test another bottom bracket and see if the issue is resolved.

Prevention
N/A

Pictures


BB can fail for a variety of reason and must be tested against a working system

Firmware

FUSEBYTE

Overview
There are four fusebytes to be set on the Atmel SOC. If these are set incorrectly or not set at all the controller is susceptible to ‘browning out.’ This will ultimately lead to read/write errors that can corrupt the controller firmware. This can lead to a variety of issues but tend to stop the controller from booting.

Symptom

  • Controller is Rev D or E
  • Controller no longer turns on

Repair
The fusebytes can be updated with a programming header. This involves opening up the controller and accessing the programming header on the RCB. The guide for this procedure can be found here.

Prevention
This is a manufacturing defect and is only preventable by reworking the controller.

Pictures

Rev - D controllers have the highest fusebyte failure rate

BLUE LED BUG

Overview
This firmware bug was prevalent on all controller containing RCB firmware version 2.1. The error involved a data logging function that could hang the RCB. The term blue led bug was coined to describe the symptom of the blue power button failing to blink during the shutdown when the bike was affected.

Symptom

  • Bike fails to charge
  • LED does not blink when the bike is being shut down
  • Bike does not provide assistance until several minutes into the ride.

Repair
Updating the firmware to version 2.2.4r permanently solves the issue. The procedure can be found here.

Prevention
Controller with firmware version 2.1 should be considered liabilities.

Pictures

If after holding down the power button the blue ring does not blink, you can be confident a blue LED bug is in effect

SELECTOR OVERDRIVE

Overview
The original electrical engineer did not follow the data sheet when designing the display driving algorithm. Firmware version 2.0 would overdrive the display to the point of physical damage. The display would become blotchy and striated with diminishing contrast.

Symptom

  • E-ink display becomes striated
  • Contrast goes from crisp black and white to grey

Repair
The display can sometimes be recovered if cycled repeatedly after a firmware update. If the damage is too excessive the display needs to be replaced. Refer to this guide to decide whether the display is recoverable. The firmware update can be found here. The rework guide can be found here

Prevention
All selectors should be running firmware version 2.1.

Pictures


The blotchy look with striations is a good indicator that the display is beyond recovery and needs to be reworked

BAC OVERVOLTAGE DETECTION

Overview
ASI made a hardware revision that left the bike susceptible to an “overvoltage fault" without a remedial firmware update. Customers noticed the bike was over sensitive and would cut out on bumps, steep hills or sudden stops.

Symptom

  • Bike cuts out on bumps
  • Bike cuts out on hills
  • After cutout motor runs in very low power mode
  • Restarting the bike temporarily fixes the issue.

Repair
Update the BAC - follow this guide.

Prevention
All controller should be running BAC version 5792.

Pictures


The BAC needs to be updated to 5792 on all bikes. The change will not show until the motor parameters are also updated.

CHARGE INTERRUPT

Overview
The charging algorithm on the Faraday bike is imperfect. It's susceptible to a range of issues including difficulty with cell balance, noise from the wall outlet, charger defects, and controller noise.

Symptom

  • LED circle is stuck on one LED during charging
  • Display does not show the full charge after a night of charging

Repair

  1. Ask the customer to try a different outlet
  2. Replace the charger
  3. If the issue persists replace the battery
  4. If the issue persists replace the controller

Prevention
N/A

Pictures


The controller will freeze on a single red LED if the charge cycle is interrupted

BOTTOM BRACKET CALIBRATION

Overview
If the bike is either sluggish of over-aggressive it would benefit from calibrating the bottom bracket. This will adjust the DC offset from the BB sensor back to zero.

Symptom

  • Sluggish assist
  • Aggressive assist

Repair
Run "calibrate BB" from the Faraday Utility.

Prevention
N/A

Pictures


To calibrate the bottom bracket, simply select calibrate BB from the Faraday Utility

Intervention Complications

SHIM INSTALLATION

Overview
Cable routing on Faraday bikes, though elegantly hidden, creates a challenge for working on the bike. The seat tube shim, in particular, has a tendency to seize up against or even damage the cables inside the frame. Dealers tend to damage the cables quite badly during hasty installations.

Symptom

  • Bike no longer powers on
  • Bike does not provide any assist
  • Bike cuts out after one pedal stroke

Repair
Tears in the insulation can often be patched with tape. It's important to only apply a thin layer of tape or risk the shim seizing. More severe cable damage will require replacing the affected component.
Checkout out the following guides:
Cortland Controller Install
Porteur Controller Install

Prevention
A few tips can help with proper shim installation:

  1. Make sure there is no twist in the wire when routed in the frame.
  2. On Porteurs, make sure one sure the top tube cable is routed to the right and the motor cable is routed to the left.
  3. Gently twist the shim as you slide it down the tube.
  4. Never use more than medium palm pressure to install the shim. If it catches its always best to reset then to continue with more force.

Pictures


Damage to the insulation like this will short out the bike every time the motor is engaged.

TORQUE SENSOR MISALIGNMENT

Overview
The TDCM sensor must be installed with the correct orientation to work properly.

Symptom

  • Sluggish assist
  • Assist only on some pedal strokes

Repair
Reinstall the BB following this guide.

Prevention
Communicate the installation to dealers before they replace the BB or battery.

Pictures


The sensor tap needs to face forward and parallel to the ground


A misaligned botttom bracket can crush the sensor

BOTTOM BRACKET SENSOR CONNECTOR STRESS

Overview
Incorrect removal of the bottom bracket can either tear the connector or stress it. This can create issues with the torque or cadence signal or stop the sensor working entirely.

Symptom

  • No assist
  • Sluggish assist
  • Assist on only part of the pedal stroke

Repair
The bottom bracket will need to be replaced.

Prevention
Always disconnect all the cables in the downtube before removing any components. The NCTE BB needs to be removed drive side first!
Refer to these guides:
Battery Install
TDCM Install
NCTE Install

Pictures


The bottom bracket sensor connector can snap off if the BB is removed incorrectly.

DAMAGED TOP TUBE PINS

Overview
Refer to:Toptube Pin Alignment

STRIPPED CORTLAND MOTOR CABLES

Overview
The motor cables in a Cortland make a hard, sharp turn into the top tube. Fishing the motor cable when replacing the controller or motor extension cable can be challenging. Tugging too hard on the connector can damage the housing or even rip off the bullet connectors.

Symptom

  • Bike fails to assist after the controller was replaced
  • Noticeable damage to the cable or connectors
  • Sporadic assist

Repair
It is pretty simple to crimp a new bullet connector or to to patch the insulation with electrical tape.

Prevention

  1. Push the motor cable in through the front of a bike while pulling it in through the back.
  2. Use the curved end of a spoke to gently hook a loop of the motor cable

Pictures


Sharp tools and damage the insulation and cause shorts

DISCONNECTED MOTOR EXTENSION CABLE

Overview
The barrel connector on a Porteur motor cable needs to be twisted to lock into place. Dealers will often forget this step and the motor cable will come undone.

Symptom

  • Bike suddenly stops assisting
  • More than one inch of the motor cable can be pulled forward, out of the top tube of the bike.

Repair
Reinstall the controller and refasten the connector.

Prevention
Double check the barrel connector is fully fasted

Pictures


It's clear this connector was not fastened correctly and may come loose in the frame

SHIPPING DAMAGE

Overview
The Faraday is a heavy bike with a heavy front wheel. Failing to package it appropriately invites a great deal of shipping damage. Areas of concern include the dropout guard and a loose front motor.

Symptom

  • Bent dropout outs
  • Tended frame from wheel impact
  • Bent spokes
  • Cracked grips

Repair
Superficial paint damage can be corrected with touch up paint. More serious damage may only be corrected by replacing the frame.

Prevention
Refer to this guide for proper boxing procedure.

Pictures


Frame damage often occurs when the wheel is just tossed into the box, unsecured

INCORRECT MOTOR PARAMETERS

Overview
The Faraday utility does not provide a clear way to identify the motor parameters installed on a bike. Often the wrong motor parameters will be on a controller, especially after it has been recently replaced. It's a good rule of thumb to always update the motor parameters after installing a controller or replacing a bottom bracket.

Symptom

  • Momentary assist and then very sluggish assist (NCTE parameters paired with TDCM BB)
  • No assist (TDCM parameters paired with NCTE BB)

Repair
Update the motor parameters following this guide.

Prevention
See above

Pictures


The motor parameters need to match both the motor and the bb sensor
